task.title: Problem: omni_schema.dependency and omni_schema.acl views are slow

data.title: Problem: omni_schema.dependency and omni_schema.acl views are slow
data.body:
This gravely impacts some of our functionality like schema diffing as we scan through all these views and `dependency` and `acl` views are the worst offenders.

Proposed solution: find a way to significantly optimize the queries

One thing is to see what else can be done for the queries themselves – at the very least in `dependency` and `acl` and maybe even other meta views. 

https://github.com/omnigres/omnigres/blob/master/extensions/omni_schema/src/meta/catalog.sql#L76

task.title: Incorporate MCP Server into Golem CLI

data.title: Incorporate MCP Server into Golem CLI
data.body:
With a new command, Golem CLI enters serve mode:

```bash
%> golem-cli --serve --serve-port 1232
%> golem-cli running MCP Server at port 1232
```

In this mode, Golem CLI creates an MCP Server that exposes different commands as different tools, and exposes relevant resources (the manifest file in the current, ancestor, and children directories) as resources.

When this ticket is completed, it should be possible to use an agent such as Claude Code to perform anything that Golem CLI can do. Moreover, all individual tools and resources must be end-to-end tested with an MCP Client that interacts with the MCP Server.

[This library](https://github.com/rust-mcp-stack/rust-mcp-sdk) looks like the one to use for Rust, but perhaps there are better options available.

task.body:

When this ticket is completed, it should be possible to use an agent such as Claude Code to perform anything that Golem CLI can do. Moreover, all individual tools and resources must be end-to-end tested with an MCP Client that interacts with the MCP Server.

[This library](https://github.com/rust-mcp-stack/rust-mcp-sdk) looks like the one to use for Rust, but perhaps there are better options available.

task.title: Warn on mismatch between global `prisma` and local `prisma` or `@prisma/client`

data.title: Warn on mismatch between global `prisma` and local `prisma` or `@prisma/client`
data.body: Using a global `prisma generate` with a different local `prisma` or `@prisma/client` might lead to problems. It might be a good idea to warn users if they are doing that and ask for explicit confirmation.

task.title: `prisma format` ends the file with a single CRLF on windows

data.title: `prisma format` ends the file with a single CRLF on windows
data.body:
### Bug description

On windows, I run `prisma format` and note the unusual file ending. The lines are all LF, but the very last line is CRLF.

This causes issue on my Linux CI where it formats it ending in LF's only, causing a diff to occur and the build to fail.

### How to reproduce

1. On windows do prisma format
2. Open in HxD or similar
3. See attached:
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1680627/127931864-fcd66391-9b31-4914-8553-f6c71b3a6fad.png)


### Expected behavior

LF's only - no CR's to exist at all

### Prisma information

<!-- Do not include your database credentials when sharing your Prisma schema! -->


### Environment & setup

Node 16
Windows/Linux

### Prisma Version

```
$ C:\p\pab\monorepo\node_modules\.bin\prisma -v
prisma               : 2.26.0
@prisma/client       : 2.28.0
Current platform     : windows
Query Engine         : query-engine 9b816b3aa13cc270074f172f30d6eda8a8ce867d (at node_modules\@prisma\engines\query-engine-windows.exe)
Migration Engine     : migration-engine-cli 9b816b3aa13cc270074f172f30d6eda8a8ce867d (at node_modules\@prisma\engines\migration-engine-windows.exe)
Introspection Engine : introspection-core 9b816b3aa13cc270074f172f30d6eda8a8ce867d (at node_modules\@prisma\engines\introspection-engine-windows.exe)
Format Binary        : prisma-fmt 9b816b3aa13cc270074f172f30d6eda8a8ce867d (at node_modules\@prisma\engines\prisma-fmt-windows.exe)
Default Engines Hash : 9b816b3aa13cc270074f172f30d6eda8a8ce867d
Studio               : 0.408.0
```

task.body:
### Bug description

On windows, I run `prisma format` and note the unusual file ending. The lines are all LF, but the very last line is CRLF.

This causes issue on my Linux CI where it formats it ending in LF's only, causing a diff to occur and the build to fail.

### How to reproduce

1. On windows do prisma format
2. Open in HxD or similar
3. See attached:
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1680627/127931864-fcd66391-9b31-4914-8553-f6c71b3a6fad.png)


### Expected behavior

LF's only - no CR's to exist at all

### Prisma information

<!-- Do not include your database credentials when sharing your Prisma schema! -->


### Environment & setup

Node 16
Windows/Linux

### Prisma Version

```
$ C:\p\pab\monorepo\node_modules\.bin\prisma -v
prisma               : 2.26.0
@prisma/client       : 2.28.0
Current platform     : windows
Query Engine         : query-engine 9b816b3aa13cc270074f172f30d6eda8a8ce867d (at node_modules\@prisma\engines\query-engine-windows.exe)
Migration Engine     : migration-engine-cli 9b816b3aa13cc270074f172f30d6eda8a8ce867d (at node_modules\@prisma\engines\migration-engine-windows.exe)
Introspection Engine : introspection-core 9b816b3aa13cc270074f172f30d6eda8a8ce867d (at node_modules\@prisma\engines\introspection-engine-windows.exe)
Format Binary        : prisma-fmt 9b816b3aa13cc270074f172f30d6eda8a8ce867d (at node_modules\@prisma\engines\prisma-fmt-windows.exe)
Default Engines Hash : 9b816b3aa13cc270074f172f30d6eda8a8ce867d
Studio               : 0.408.0
```

task.title: Output path of current Prisma in `-v`

data.title: Output path of current Prisma in `-v`
data.body:
## Problem

This is a situation that can happen:
```
--- yarn prisma -v ---
warning package.json: No license field
prisma               : 2.26.0-dev.7
@prisma/client       : 2.26.0-dev.7
Current platform     : debian-openssl-1.1.x
Query Engine         : query-engine c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/query-engine-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Migration Engine     : migration-engine-cli c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/migration-engine-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Introspection Engine : introspection-core c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/introspection-engine-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Format Binary        : prisma-fmt c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/prisma-fmt-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Default Engines Hash : c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922
Studio               : 0.402.0
--- ls node_modules/@prisma/engines/ ---
ls: cannot access 'node_modules/@prisma/engines/': No such file or directory
```

As you can see `yarn prisma -v` tells us the engines comes from `node_modules/@prisma/engines`, but when you try to list that directory, it is actually not present.

What is happening here is that `yarn prisma` is actually from a few folders _above_ our project. This is kinda visible when you look to not run `yarn -s` but just `yarn`:
```
codespace ➜ /workspaces/e2e-tests/platforms-serverless/firebase-functions (janpio-patch-5 ✗) $ yarn prisma -v
yarn run v1.22.10
warning package.json: No license field
$ /workspaces/e2e-tests/node_modules/.bin/prisma -v
prisma               : 2.25.0-dev.36
@prisma/client       : 2.25.0-dev.36
...
```

## Suggested solution

Output the directory of where the executed `prisma` is from, either similar to Yarn the absolute path to the binary in `node_modules`, or the folder where the `package.json` that is responsible for the installation of Prisma comes from.

## Alternatives

Rely on `yarn` itself to give that information. Will not work with `npx` unfortunately for example.

task.body:
## Problem

This is a situation that can happen:
```
--- yarn prisma -v ---
warning package.json: No license field
prisma               : 2.26.0-dev.7
@prisma/client       : 2.26.0-dev.7
Current platform     : debian-openssl-1.1.x
Query Engine         : query-engine c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/query-engine-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Migration Engine     : migration-engine-cli c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/migration-engine-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Introspection Engine : introspection-core c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/introspection-engine-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Format Binary        : prisma-fmt c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922 (at node_modules/@prisma/engines/prisma-fmt-debian-openssl-1.1.x)
Default Engines Hash : c838e79f39885bc8e1611849b1eb28b5bb5bc922
Studio               : 0.402.0
--- ls node_modules/@prisma/engines/ ---
ls: cannot access 'node_modules/@prisma/engines/': No such file or directory
```

As you can see `yarn prisma -v` tells us the engines comes from `node_modules/@prisma/engines`, but when you try to list that directory, it is actually not present.

What is happening here is that `yarn prisma` is actually from a few folders _above_ our project. This is kinda visible when you look to not run `yarn -s` but just `yarn`:
```
codespace ➜ /workspaces/e2e-tests/platforms-serverless/firebase-functions (janpio-patch-5 ✗) $ yarn prisma -v
yarn run v1.22.10
warning package.json: No license field
$ /workspaces/e2e-tests/node_modules/.bin/prisma -v
prisma               : 2.25.0-dev.36
@prisma/client       : 2.25.0-dev.36
...
```

## Suggested solution

Output the directory of where the executed `prisma` is from, either similar to Yarn the absolute path to the binary in `node_modules`, or the folder where the `package.json` that is responsible for the installation of Prisma comes from.

## Alternatives

Rely on `yarn` itself to give that information. Will not work with `npx` unfortunately for example.

task.title: CVE-2021-22941 - Citrix ShareFile - Broken Access Control 💰

data.title: CVE-2021-22941 - Citrix ShareFile - Broken Access Control 💰
data.body:
### Description: 
> Citrix ShareFile Storage Zones Controller before 5.11.20 contains a broken access control vulnerability caused by improper access restrictions, letting unauthenticated attackers remotely compromise the system, exploit requires no authentication.

#### Severity: `Critical`

#### POC: 
- https://github.com/hoavt18/CVE-2021-22941
- https://github.com/hoav18/CVE-2021-22941

### KEV: True

### Shodan Query: `NA`

> Acceptance Criteria: The template must include a complete POC and should not rely solely on version-based detection. Contributors are required to provide debug data(`-debug`) along with the template to help the triage team with validation or can also share a vulnerable environment like docker file. 

> Rewards will only be given once the template is fully validated by the team. Templates that are incomplete or invalid will not be accepted. Avoid adding code templates for CVEs that can be achieved using HTTP, TCP, or JavaScript. Such templates are blocked by default and won’t produce results, so we prioritize creating templates with other protocols unless exceptions are made.

You can check the FAQ for the Nuclei Templates Community Rewards Program [here](https://github.com/projectdiscovery/nuclei-templates/blob/main/Community-Rewards-FAQ.md).

task.title: CVE-2021-21980 - vSphere Web Client - Path Traversal 💰

data.title: CVE-2021-21980 - vSphere Web Client - Path Traversal 💰
data.body:
### Description: 
> vSphere Web Client (FLEX/Flash) contains an unauthorized arbitrary file read caused by insecure file access in the web client, letting attackers with network access to port 443 on vCenter Server access sensitive information, exploit requires network access to port 443.

#### Severity: `High`

#### POC: 
- https://github.com/Osyanina/westone-CVE-2022-1388-scanner
- https://github.com/Osyanina/westone-CVE-2021-21980-scanner

task.title: CVE-2021-4073 - RegistrationMagic - Authentication Bypass 💰

data.title: CVE-2021-4073 - RegistrationMagic - Authentication Bypass 💰
data.body:
### Description: 
> RegistrationMagic WordPress plugin versions <= 5.0.1.7 contain an authentication bypass caused by missing identity validation in social_login_using_email(), letting unauthenticated users log in as any site user, exploit requires knowing a valid username.

#### Severity: `Critical`

#### POC: 
- https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2021/12/authentication-bypass-vulnerability-patched-in-user-registration-plugin/

### KEV: True

### Shodan Query: `NA`

> Acceptance Criteria: The template must include a complete POC and should not rely solely on version-based detection. Contributors are required to provide debug data(`-debug`) along with the template to help the triage team with validation or can also share a vulnerable environment like docker file.

You can check the FAQ for the Nuclei Templates Community Rewards Program [here](https://github.com/projectdiscovery/nuclei-templates/blob/main/Community-Rewards-FAQ.md).

task.title: CVE-2022-31199 - Netwrix Auditor - Remote Code Execution 💰

data.title: CVE-2022-31199 - Netwrix Auditor - Remote Code Execution 💰
data.body:
### Description: 
> Netwrix Auditor User Activity Video Recording component contains remote code execution caused by vulnerabilities in the underlying protocol, letting unauthenticated attackers execute arbitrary code as SYSTEM, exploit requires network access.

#### Severity: `Critical`

#### POC: 
- https://bishopfox.com/blog/netwrix-auditor-advisory

### KEV: True

### Shodan Query: `NA`

> Acceptance Criteria: The template must include a complete POC and should not rely solely on version-based detection. Contributors are required to provide debug data(`-debug`) along with the template to help the triage team with validation or can also share a vulnerable environment like docker file. 

> Rewards will only be given once the template is fully validated by the team. Templates that are incomplete or invalid will not be accepted. Avoid adding code templates for CVEs that can be achieved using HTTP, TCP, or JavaScript. Such templates are blocked by default and won’t produce results, so we prioritize creating templates with other protocols unless exceptions are made.

You can check the FAQ for the Nuclei Templates Community Rewards Program [here](https://github.com/projectdiscovery/nuclei-templates/blob/main/Community-Rewards-FAQ.md).

task.title: CVE-2023-25158 - GeoTools - SQL Injection 💰

data.title: CVE-2023-25158 - GeoTools - SQL Injection 💰
data.body:
### Description: 
> GeoTools < 27.4, 28.2 contains a sql_injection caused by unsanitized OGC Filter expressions in JDBCDataStore, letting attackers execute arbitrary SQL commands, exploit requires executing malicious filters.

#### Severity: `Critical`

task.title: CVE-2023-27532 - Veeam Backup & Replication - Credential Disclosure 💰

data.title: CVE-2023-27532 - Veeam Backup & Replication - Credential Disclosure 💰
data.body:
### Description: 
> Veeam Backup & Replication contains a vulnerability that allows encrypted credentials stored in the configuration database to be obtained, letting attackers access backup infrastructure hosts, exploit requires access to the configuration database.

#### Severity: `High`

- https://vulncheck.com/xdb/a0eedd90601f

task.title: [Enhancement]: Filebrowser for Containerlevel

data.title: [Enhancement]: Filebrowser for Containerlevel
data.body:
### Request Type

New Feature

### Description

I would like to get the ability to have a filebrowser on containerlevel. The idea is, that, for example, one can download or upload config file or images or any other type of files within the scope of the container. This includes mounts and also the overlay fs. Just a filebrowser for everything that you can see inside the container itself. 

Prio 1: mapped folders
Prio 2: everything "inside" the container. 

It should support: 

- Browsing like windows explorer or nautilus under linux
- Upload and download single files
- Upload and download folders
- Create folders
- Delete folders / files
- Check Filesize
- Check permissions (optional: set them)

task.body:
### Request Type

New Feature

### Description

The idea is, that, for example, one can download or upload config file or images or any other type of files within the scope of the container. This includes mounts and also the overlay fs. Just a filebrowser for everything that you can see inside the container itself. 

Prio 1: mapped folders
Prio 2: everything "inside" the container. 

It should support: 

- Browsing like windows explorer or nautilus under linux
- Upload and download single files
- Upload and download folders
- Create folders
- Delete folders / files
- Check Filesize
- Check permissions (optional: set them)

task.title: [Enhancement]: Use pgBackRest for Postgres backups

data.title: [Enhancement]: Use pgBackRest for Postgres backups
data.body:
### Request Type

New Feature

### Description

Implement support for using pgBackRest for Postgres backups, ideally as the new default for Postgres.

This will enable incremental backups and make the backup experience 100x better for large DBs using Postgres. The current backup system is good, but starts to have failures for larger DBs. The current backup system also causes huge S3 bills for larger DBs (ex. nightly backups of 100gb DBs start to add up).

This must also support the backups API.

$500 USD bounty once this is merged into https://app.coolify.io's instance and I've verified it works on Postgres DBs with 100gb of data in them.

---

This bounty is funded by [Hack Club](https://hackclub.com), a charity that supports teenagers who love computers and electronics! We previously funded database SSL support and the creation of the backups API.

task.body:
### Request Type

New Feature

### Description

Implement support for using pgBackRest for Postgres backups, ideally as the new default for Postgres.

This will enable incremental backups and make the backup experience 100x better for large DBs using Postgres. The current backup system is good, but starts to have failures for larger DBs. The current backup system also causes huge S3 bills for larger DBs (ex. nightly backups of 100gb DBs start to add up).

This must also support the backups API.

$500 USD bounty once this is merged into https://app.coolify.io's instance and I've verified it works on Postgres DBs with 100gb of data in them.

---

This bounty is funded by [Hack Club](https://hackclub.com), a charity that supports teenagers who love computers and electronics! We previously funded database SSL support and the creation of the backups API.

task.title: [Enhancement]: Update Clickhouse template

data.title: [Enhancement]: Update Clickhouse template
data.body:
### Request Type

Improvement

### Description

Currently the Clickhouse template is using `bitnamilegacy/clickhouse` which is not updated anymore.
I believe the correct image to be used is `clickhouse:lts`.

Simply changing the image doesn't work, probably just different environment variables.
There should be a migration path so data won't be lost (written explanation is fine).

task.body:
### Request Type

Improvement

### Description

Currently the Clickhouse template is using `bitnamilegacy/clickhouse` which is not updated anymore.
I believe the correct image to be used is `clickhouse:lts`.

Simply changing the image doesn't work, probably just different environment variables.
There should be a migration path so data won't be lost (written explanation is fine).
